    Virtual Screening Approach and Investigation of Structure–Activity Relationships To Discover Novel Bacterial Topoisomerase Inhibitors Targeting Gram-Positive and Gram-Negative Pathogens

    • Gabriele Magarò
      Gabriele Magarò

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Bacterial resistance is increasing rapidly, requiring urgent identification of new antibacterial drugs that are effective against multidrug-resistant pathogens. Novel bacterial topoisomerase inhibitors (NBTIs) provide a new strategy for investigating the well-validated DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV targets while preventing cross-resistance issues. On this basis, starting from a virtual screening campaign and subsequent structure-based hit optimization guided by X-ray studies, a novel class of piperazine-like NBTIs with outstanding enzymatic activity against Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV was identified. Notably, compounds (±)-33, (±)-35, and (±)-36 with potent and balanced multitarget enzymatic profiles exhibited excellent efficacy against selected Gram-positive and Gram-negative pathogens, as well as clinically relevant resistant strains. Overall, the new NBTI chemotype described herein, owing to the broad-spectrum antibacterial activity and favorable in vitro safety profile, might serve as a basis for the development of novel treatments against serious infections.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The increasing prevalence of resistant bacteria, such as methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE), and fluoroquinolone-resistant pathogens, represents a global health burden and poses the need for novel and effective antibiotics.(1−5) In this respect, the discovery of antibacterial compounds with new mechanisms of action might be desirable to reduce the likelihood of the emergence of resistance, improve activity against persistent infections, and provide improved safety.(6) Nevertheless, considerable research efforts remain dedicated to the development of new antibiotics that act on well-established and clinically validated targets. In particular, DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, which are members of the bacterial type IIA topoisomerase family, continue to attract significant attention from the scientific community. Both enzymes, which are known to regulate DNA topology during replication, bind to double-stranded DNA and cut the phosphate backbone, enabling the strand to be untangled or unwound. DNA gyrase introduces negative supercoils into DNA,(7) while topoisomerase IV is largely responsible for the decatenation of the sister chromatids at the end of the replication process.(8) Both enzymes are heterotetramers; DNA gyrase is composed of GyrA2/GyrB2 subunits, and topoisomerase IV consists of ParC2/ParE2 subunits.
    Bacterial type IIA topoisomerases are well-validated targets as fluoroquinolones interact with the GyrA and ParC subunits of DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, respectively. Specifically, fluoroquinolones bind to the cleavage-ligation site located in the GyrA and ParC subunits, stabilize the double-stranded breaks in DNA, block the replication process, and finally induce an SOS response that leads to bacterial cell death.(9) Although fluoroquinolones have been used as successful frontline drugs for more than 50 years to treat broad-spectrum bacterial infections, resistance to these therapeutics has recently emerged due to mutations that alter the accumulation of these drugs in bacterial cells and affect molecular target recognition.(10) Therefore, new drug discovery approaches and technologies have been envisaged to identify novel topoisomerase inhibitors that can circumnavigate these resistance mechanisms and maintain clinical efficacy.
    In recent years, several pharmaceutical companies have independently discovered new classes of novel (nonfluoroquinolone) bacterial type IIA topoisomerase inhibitors (NBTIs), and the results of this research have gradually entered the public domain (compounds A–G in Figure 1).(11−26)
    Importantly, several NBTIs showed lack of cross-resistance with fluoroquinolones and potent broad-spectrum antibacterial activity against the most problematic Gram-positive and Gram-negative pathogens, including efficacy in mouse models of infections. Notwithstanding the well-established cornerstones in the rational development of NBTIs, hERG liability still remains a pivotal encumbrance for their progression into clinical trials.(27) In this respect, Novexel discontinued the development of NXL101 (compound A) due to unacceptable QT interval prolongation in healthy subjects during the early clinical phase.(12) GlaxoSmithKline made more progress, having disclosed GSK2140944 (gepotidacin, compound B). Recently, GSK2140944 completed phase II clinical evaluation for the treatment of uncomplicated urogenital gonorrhea caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae and for acute bacterial skin and skin structure infections caused by S. aureus.(16,17) Additionally, GSK2140944 is in preclinical development for anthrax, plague, and tularemia infections.(18)
    Overall, the use of NBTIs is considered a suitable strategy for targeting clinically validated topoisomerase enzymes while restoring therapeutic efficacy. The mechanism of action of NBTIs was first disclosed in 2010,(28) when Bax et al. reported the crystal structure of GSK299423 (compound G in Figure 1) in complex with S. aureus DNA gyrase and DNA (PDB code 2XCS). The X-ray model unambiguously revealed the NBTI binding mode, confirming a binding site different from the one occupied by fluoroquinolones and highlighting key interactions of the ligand with both the DNA strand and GyrA subunits.
    To the best of our knowledge, the binding mode of NBTIs to DNA gyrases of other bacterial species, as well as topoisomerase IV enzymes, is unknown. However, comparison of the whole amino acid sequence of S. aureus DNA gyrase with that of S. aureus topoisomerase IV shows that these enzymes share a high degree of identity (35%). Similar levels of homology are also observed across species. Indeed, E. coli DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV exhibit 47 and 35% identity with S. aureus DNA gyrase, respectively (Figure S1). Furthermore, a closer analysis revealed that highly conserved amino acids are present in the NBTI-binding regions of the DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV enzymes of both S. aureus and E. coli, demonstrating that the key residues involved in the NBTI interaction are retained (Figure 2).
    Indeed, the first shells of interacting residues in the four enzymes differ at one position only (a conservative change of Met75 in S. aureus DNA gyrase). In particular, Met75 in S. aureus DNA gyrase is replaced by Ile in E. coli DNA gyrase and Leu in E. coli topoisomerase IV. This finding strongly suggests a conserved NBTI-binding region in all the considered type IIA topoisomerases, regardless of bacterial origin. Therefore, it is highly conceivable that small molecules that can simultaneously bind to DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV enzymes from different microbial species could be identified, providing broad-spectrum antibacterial agents with a multitarget mechanism of action. Indeed, multitarget ligands represent an important prospect in antibacterial research as, although they will not overcome the issue of resistance in a long term, they might delay its onset and guarantee much improved longevity over single targeted agents. In fact, to develop high-level resistance to a multitargeted drug, bacteria would need sequential mutations in more than one essential target. Thus, if the inhibitory activity is well balanced against multiple targets, the likelihood of single-step resistance would be decreased. Importantly, successful systemic monotherapeutic antibacterials, such as fluoroquinolones, have been retrospectively discovered to inhibit DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV simultaneously.(29) Therefore, the prospective design of multitarget ligands is an inviting opportunity for the development of effective monotherapeutic drugs that might even be beneficial over combination therapy in terms of simplification of the therapeutic regimen and pharmacokinetic profile, as well as obviation of possible drug–drug interactions.(6)
    On these premises, we embarked on a drug discovery program (Figure 3) aimed at identifying a novel class of NBTIs. Specifically, a computer-aided drug design strategy using (i) virtual screening, (ii) shape screening, and (iii) pharmacophore search was applied.
    The resulting virtual hits, independently selected from the three steps described above, were visually inspected and cherry-picked to be tested for inhibitory activity in DNA gyrase supercoiling and topoisomerase IV decatenation assays. From these initial investigations, an original class of piperazine derivatives was identified for further structure-based (SB) optimization. This campaign exploited an X-ray crystallographic study that retrospectively confirmed the predicted binding mode. Extensive medicinal chemistry research, resulting in compounds 1–36, provided consistent structure–activity relationships (SARs) and led to the identification of potent NBTIs with excellent enzymatic and whole-cell activity against different bacterial strains.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Identification of Hit Molecules by a Virtual Screening Campaign

    At the start of the computer-aided drug design investigation, the only relevant 3D cocrystal structure available for NBTI-like compounds was that of GSK299423 complexed with S. aureus DNA gyrase (PDB code 2XCS).(28) Nevertheless, the chemical structures of several NBTIs were already published in the public domain, thus providing an opportunity for integrated structure-based virtual screening (SBVS) and ligand/pharmacophore-based virtual screening (LBVS) (Figure 3).
    To evaluate the suitability of the GSK299423-S. aureus DNA gyrase 3D structure(28) for virtual screening, the Schrödinger’s Glide program was used.(30) The first step was to ensure that simple redocking correctly reproduced the information contained within the crystal structure, and the cognate ligand scored suitably high (Figure S2). Simultaneously, a set of 44 known active compounds from the NBTI-related literature (Table S1) were docked, and the poses of these compounds were inspected for basic concordance with the NBTI structural outline. The shape generated by docking (Figure S3) confirmed the conserved binding mode of the 44 NBTIs and the overall similarity to the GSK299423 pose, which was faithfully reproduced and received a very favorable “docking score” (−11.7 kcal/mol).
    The ability of this structural model to enrich for NBTIs was then tested by combining ligands from the literature with a decoy dataset. The Glide decoy set (available from the Schrödinger Inc. website https://www.schrodinger.com/glide) was downloaded and filtered to extract only those decoys that had physicochemical properties that were similar to those of known NBTIs (Figure S4). This complete database was then run through a “mock” SBVS. As shown in Figure 4, the enrichment factor (EF) of the 44 compounds suggests a favorable performance in the early recognition with Glide using default settings (see the Experimental Section for further details).
    Given the expected performance of the SBVS protocol, we subsequently set up the main screening. To explore a large area of chemical space and increase the chemical diversity in the virtual screening campaign, a collection of over 30,000 compounds was prepared by including both corporate and commercial libraries, the latter being selected as described in the Experimental Section. The 3D ligand structures were subsequently docked into the S. aureus DNA gyrase model (PDB code 2XCS).(28) The best docking results (docking score ≤ −7.00 kcal/mol) were then visually inspected for key interactions with the binding site, with particular emphasis on the presence of a central amino group. This procedure resulted in approximately 500 virtual hits from different chemical classes.
    With only a single 3D structure available (PDB code 2XCS)(28) at the time of investigation, there was the chance of a significant bias entering the results. Consequently, we augmented the SBVS with a pharmacophore-based model derived solely from the structures of known NBTIs. In this regard, eight compounds from the literature (Table S2),(31) including GSK299423, were carefully evaluated on the basis of chemical diversity, and a conformationally constrained subset was generated. As a class, NBTIs consist of three structural motifs: (i) an unsaturated heterocyclic left-hand side (LHS), (ii) a mono- or bicyclic right-hand side (RHS), and (iii) a largely aliphatic linker, which joins the LHS and RHS portions in an appropriate conformation (Figure 5).(32)
    The Phase pharmacophore modeling package(33) was used to identify the low-energy conformations that maximized the overlapping of the three portions of the NBTI structures. From this alignment, several different pharmacophore hypotheses were generated, combining default settings and custom features in Phase using either the vector or the projected point description for the acceptor groups. A minimum of 75% of the literature molecules had to match with the hypothesis. The two best models had five features: two hydrogen bond acceptors (A) and one ring (R) modeling the interactions with DNA, one hydrogen bond donor (D) or positive group (P) describing the interactions with Asp83, and finally, one aromatic/hydrophobic ring (R) representing the hydrophobic group that is nestled within the protein. According to the specific combination of the molecular features, the two selected pharmacophores were indicated as follows: (i) AADRR and (ii) AAPRR (Figure S5). Following the standard practice in virtual screening, the pharmacophore models were first assessed for their ability to recognize the bioactive conformation of GSK299423 and then, in terms of EF, using the 44 compounds and decoy dataset (Figure 6). All five sites matched well with the dataset compounds. These two pharmacophore models were then used to screen the 30,000 compound library discussed earlier, specifying that the compound must match all five features to be considered as a hit. Approximately 200 compounds were selected using this approach.
    All NBTIs have a fairly distinctive shape, and given the speed of shape-based virtual screening,(34) it seemed appropriate that an additional shape-based screen was conducted. The literature and decoy ligands were used to validate the shape model. This procedure retrieved a marked number of active compounds in the top 2% of the ranked dataset and full recovery in the top 5% (Table S3). In light of these results, searching the 30,000 compound library using identical settings allowed us to identify approximately 200 additional compounds.
    In total, the computational screens aggregated approximately 900 virtual hits. Moreover, an additional set of filters and clustering was applied to remove redundancy in the selected compounds (see the Experimental Section for further details). Eventually, 162 compounds (ID-9 to ID-162) were selected and taken forward for experimental screening.

    Biological Testing

    Enzyme inhibition, expressed as an IC50 value, was assessed against DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV from both S. aureus and E. coli in supercoiling and decatenation assays, respectively.
    Among the 162 tested compounds, 12 (selected according to the methods and ranking reported in Table S4) were confirmed to inhibit one or both enzymes in the supercoiling and decatenation assays, and the IC50 values are reported in Table 1.
    Table 1. Results of the Biological Assay of Identified Compounds with Inhibitory Activity against DNA Gyrase and Topoisomerase IV of E. coli and S. aureus
     IC50 (μM)a
     E. colibS. aureusc
    compdDNA gyrasedtopoisomerase IVeDNA gyrasedtopoisomerase IVe
    ID-9>800>80063>800
    ID-14>800>800265>800
    ID-46>8004.127.8100–200
    ID-62>800>800378.2109.1
    ID-64>800301>400f>800
    ID-72>800>800>80050.1
    ID-81>800>80042.1500–800
    ID-96>800115.7104.9>400f
    ID-110>800>80055365.7
    ID-120>800>800104>800
    ID-126>800>800145.8513
    ID-13011213020489
    a

    IC50 values were calculated on concentration–response curves using the global curve fit nonlinear regression tool. Compounds were assayed at eight concentrations in duplicate with twofold or half-log dilutions starting from 800 μM.

    b

    E. coli ATCC 25922.

    c

    S. aureus ATCC 29213.

    d

    Compounds were tested in DNA gyrase supercoiling assay kit (Norwich, U.K.).

    e

    Compounds were tested in topoisomerase IV decatenation assay kit (Norwich, U.K.).

    f

    Compounds were tested starting from 400 μM concentration.

    Four out of the 12 active compounds (ID-46, ID-62, ID-110, and ID-130) exhibited IC50 values lower than 400 μM for at least one DNA gyrase and one topoisomerase IV enzyme, resulting in dual inhibitors. Two of the most promising hits, piperazine ID-130 and aminopiperidine ID-46 (Figure 7), showed potency toward S. aureus DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV in the double-digit and high-micromolar ranges, respectively. Importantly, compound ID-130, with promising inhibitory activity also against both E. coli enzymes, was tested for antibacterial potency (expressed as minimum inhibitory concentration or MIC) toward a small but representative panel of Gram-negative and Gram-positive strains comprising E. coli ATCC 25922, S. aureus ATCC 29213, and S. aureus BAA-1720 (known as MRSA, a fluoroquinolone-resistant strain). MICs were determined according to the guidelines of the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI).
    Notably, despite being less potent than the reference compound ciprofloxacin in Gram-negative E. coli (MIC = 256 μg/mL vs 0.016 μg/mL) and Gram-positive S. aureus (MIC = 16 μg/mL vs 0.5 μg/mL), ID-130 demonstrated more pronounced antibacterial activity against fluoroquinolone-resistant Gram-positive strains, such as S. aureus BAA-1720 (MIC = 32 μg/mL vs >64 μg/mL) (Table 2).
    Table 2. Enzymatic and Antibacterial Activity of the Selected Hit Compound (ID-130)
     IC50 (μM)aMIC (μg/mL)b
     DNA gyrasectopoisomerase IVd   
    compdE. colieS. aureusfE. colieS. aureusfE. colieS. aureusfS. aureus BAA-1720g
    ciprofloxacin118751130.0160.5>64
    ID-130112201304892561632
    a

    IC50 values were calculated on concentration–response curves using the global curve fit nonlinear regression tool. Compounds were assayed at eight concentrations in duplicate with twofold or half-log dilutions starting from 800 μM.

    b

    Minimum inhibitory concentration were determined by the broth microdilution method according to guidelines of the CLSI.

    c

    Compounds were tested in DNA gyrase supercoiling assay kit (Norwich, U.K.).

    d

    Compounds were tested in topoisomerase IV decatenation assay kit (Norwich, U.K.).

    e

    E. coli ATCC 25922.

    f

    S. aureus ATCC 29213.

    g

    Methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA).

    X-ray Crystallographic Structure Determination

    Hit compound ID-130 was submitted for X-ray crystallography to confirm the putative binding mode proposed by computational studies. Initial attempts to cocrystallize the ternary system composed of ID-130, S. aureus DNA gyrase, and a short strand of DNA were not successful. Therefore, docking models based on the 2XCS structure(28) were used as references for much of the SB optimization process.
    Nonetheless, a cocrystal structure of ID-130 in S. aureus DNA gyrase truncated gyrB27-A56 (specifically GyrB27-A56 (GKdel/Tyr123Phe)) fusion construct and 20 base-pair synthetic DNA binding site fragment was finally obtained (PDB code 6FM4) at a 2.7 Å resolution (Figure 8) (see the Supporting Information for the experimental details).
    The comparatively low resolution of this structure made detailed modeling of the complex difficult, in particular, the precise conformation of some of the most flexible sections of the ligand. However, the result was fairly consistent with similar structures in the public domain; for example, the protein and DNA chains could be convincingly superimposed onto the 2XCS structure, yielding an RMSD of 0.35 Å. Additionally, the 3D structure was even consistent with the previous modeling work carried out on ID-130. The isoquinoline ring (LHS) was bound between the two central base pairs of the stretched DNA. The hydrogen of the amidic group at the bottom of the linker was engaged in H-bonding interactions with the carboxylate of Asp83′, and the phenyl moiety (RHS) pointed toward the hydrophobic pocket between the two DNA gyrase subunits.

    Chemistry

    After identification of compounds ID-130 and ID-46, a hit optimization campaign was started to improve the enzymatic and antibacterial activities of these compounds via iterative cycles of SB drug design and synthesis based on biochemical and whole-cell screening. This effort generated a novel series of N-linked piperazines (1–36 in Tables 3–6).
    Table 3. SAR of the Left-Hand Side (LHS)
    a

    IC50 values were calculated on concentration–response curves using the global curve fit nonlinear regression tool. Compounds were assayed at eight concentrations in duplicate with twofold or half-log dilutions starting from 100 μM.

    b

    Compounds were tested in DNA gyrase supercoiling assay kit (Norwich, U.K.).

    c

    Compounds were tested in topoisomerase IV decatenation assay kit (Norwich, U.K.).

    d

    E. coli ATCC 25922.

    e

    S. aureus ATCC 29213.

    Compounds 1–36 (Tables 3–6) were synthesized by different synthetic approaches, as depicted in Schemes 1–8. Compounds 1–4, 6, 11, 12, 14–23, 27, 28, and 30 were obtained via a multistep synthetic route, starting from the proper commercially available 1-chloroisoquinoline reagent (Scheme 1).
    tert-Butyl 4-(isoquinolin-1-yl)piperazine-1-carboxylates Ia–Ih were obtained by an SNAr reaction of the proper 1-chloroisoquinoline with tert-butyl piperazine-1-carboxylate. Subsequent deprotection of Ia–Ih under standard conditions afforded the corresponding piperazines IIa–IIh. N-protected amines IIIa–IIIj were obtained either by (i) alkylation of IIa–IIg using tert-butyl (3-bromopropyl)carbamate (for intermediates IIIa–IIIg) or tert-butyl (2-bromoethyl)carbamate (for intermediate IIIh) or (ii) reduction of the iminium intermediate generated in situ by reaction of amine IIa with tert-butyl (3-oxocyclobutyl)carbamate (for cis and trans isomers IIIi and IIIj, respectively). N-methylation of tert-butyl {3-[4-(isoquinolin-1-yl)piperazin-1-yl]propyl}carbamate IIIa led to intermediate IVa. Subsequently, Boc-protected intermediates IIIa–IIIj and IVa underwent deprotection under standard conditions to afford primary amines Va–Vk. Finally, the reaction of amines Va–Vk with the proper pyran-2-ones VIa–VIj, prepared by triflation of the corresponding hydroxyl precursors, provided the final compounds 1–4, 6, 11, 12, 14–23, 27, 28, and 30.
    The synthetic route for compounds 5, 7–10, and 13 involved the preparation of the key Boc-protected common intermediate VIIa, starting from VIa and the commercial tert-butyl 4-(3-aminopropyl)piperazine-1-carboxylate. Subsequent deprotection of VIIa afforded amines VIIIa, which was coupled in a parallel fashion with the proper chloroisoquinolines or chloronaphthyridines to afford target compounds 5, 7–10, and 13 (Scheme 2).
    For synthesis of the O-derivative 24, the hydroxyl intermediate IXa was prepared via a MW-assisted SNAr of 1-(3-hydroxy-1-propyl)piperazine on 1-chloroisoquinoline. Conversion of the hydroxyl derivative IXa into mesylate Xa followed by reaction with 4-hydroxy-2H-1-benzopyran-2-one under standard coupling conditions provided the target compound (Scheme 3).
    Amide 25 was prepared using a similar strategy as described for compound 24 (Scheme 4). Amide XIa, prepared by the reaction of 1-chloro-7-fluoroisoquinoline with 3-(piperazin-1-yl)propenamide, was coupled by Buchwald cross-coupling with coumarin VIa in the presence of Pd(dba)2 and Xantphos as the catalyst/ligand system.
    Compound 26 was synthesized as depicted in Scheme 5. Intermediate XIIa, prepared by SNAr of piperazin-2-one on 1-chloroisoquinoline, was alkylated with N-Boc-3-bromopropylamine to give the protected amine XIIIa. Subsequent deprotection of XIIIa to obtain XIVa and reaction with VIa provided the target compound.
    According to Scheme 6, the synthesis of the hydroxyl derivatives (R)-29, (S)-29, (R)-34, and racemic (±)-35 and (±)-36 involved the preparation of intermediates XVa–XVd.
    Compounds (R)-XVa and (S)-XVb were prepared via the ring-opening reaction of (2R)-N-(2,3-epoxypropyl)phthalimide and (2S)-N-(2,3-epoxypropyl)phthalimide by piperazine IIb, respectively, followed by treatment with methylamine. Intermediates (±)-XVc and (±)-XVd were obtained by the reaction of racemic epichlorohydrine with piperazines IIb and IIh, respectively, followed by conversion of the resulting chloride into azide and its catalytic reduction to the corresponding amine. To afford the target compounds, the resulting amines XVa–XVd were then reacted with triflate VIa or chloride XVIa and XVIb, prepared via chlorination of the corresponding 4-hydroxy-coumarin or 4-hydroxy-2H-1,3-benzoxazin-2-one with phosphorus pentachloride.
    Synthesis of compound (±)-31 involved the preparation of chloride XVIIa from 4-methylcoumarin and 3-chloropropanoyl chloride using LiHDMS. The SN2 reaction of XVIIa with 7-fluoro-1-(piperazin-1-yl)isoquinoline IIb led to ketone XVIIIa, which underwent subsequent reduction of the carbonyl group by sodium borohydride to yield the target compound (Scheme 7).
    The synthesis of compounds (±)-32 and (±)-33 is illustrated in Scheme 8.
    Reaction of triflate VIb with (±)-tert-butyl 4-(3-amino-2-hydroxypropyl)piperazine-1-carboxylate provided the Boc-protected intermediate (±)-XIXa. Subsequent amine deprotection of (±)-XIXa provided amine (±)-XXa, which was used in the final SNAr reaction with 5-chloro-1,6-naphthyridine and 1-chloro-3-fluoro-7-methoxyisoquinoline to afford (±)-32 and (±)-33, respectively.

    Merging and Modeling Approaches

    Starting from the X-ray structural data and docking model (Figure S6) generated for ID-130 and ID-46, respectively, we envisaged a merging approach to combine the isoquinoline moiety of ID-130 (LHS) and the 4-aminocoumarin portion of ID-46 (RHS) to form a new chemical entity (Figure 7). This strategy resulted in compound 1 (Figure 7), which retained the same binding pose as the parent hits and showed improved enzymatic activity.
    Compound 1 inhibited E. coli DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV and S. aureus DNA gyrase with IC50 values ranging from 0.5 to 14 μM, whereas the inhibitory activity toward S. aureus topoisomerase IV was 90 μM, showing a favorable multitarget profile and confirming the value of the applied merging strategy.
    To help rationalize the obtained enzymatic data and assess the solvent contribution to the target binding affinity of compound 1, Schrödinger’s WaterMap application(35,36) was used. WaterMap is a molecular dynamics (MD)-based computational method that uses statistical mechanics to describe the thermodynamic properties (entropy, enthalpy, and free energy) of water molecules (hydration sites) in proteins and protein–ligand complexes, thus revealing the energetic effects of solvation and desolvation on binding and ultimately guiding hit/lead optimization. WaterMap analysis of compound 1 (Figures 9 and 10) modeled into the S. aureus DNA gyrase crystal structure (PDB code 2XCS)(28) showed that the LHS and RHS moieties replaced unstable hydration sites within the DNA-binding region and the hydrophobic pocket at the interface between the GyrA chains, respectively. These findings supported the promising inhibitory activity of compound 1, which served as the basis for further SB drug design efforts.
    Starting from compound 1, an optimization strategy was applied, providing novel analogues by modifying the three identifiable structural motifs: LHS (isoquinoline), RHS (coumarin), and linker (aminopropyl-piperazine).

    LHS SAR

    LHS modifications were centered on the introduction of different substituents at various positions on the bicyclic ring of compound 1, as well as replacement of the isoquinoline moiety by other heterocycles, affording compounds 2–13 (Table 3).
    As anticipated above, WaterMap studies indicated that the nitrogen of the isoquinoline of 1 was relevant for binding because this moiety replaced an unstable hydration site and allowed the ligand to better fit into the natural structure of the solvent in and around the DNA strand (Figure 9). This result was consistent with the loss of activity in the supercoiling and decatenation assays for the equivalent napthyl-bearing ligand (data not shown).
    Furthermore, collateral “high-energy” hydration sites, close to the isoquinoline moiety and accessible from the 7-position of the bicyclic system, were identified. Therefore, the introduction of different 7-substituents on the isoquinoline ring was predicted to possibly displace these unstable water molecules and increase binding affinity. The resulting compounds 2–7 showed an enhanced and more balanced multitarget profile with respect to the parent hit 1, validating the rational design. Specifically, compounds 2 (7-F) and 3 (7-Cl) retained submicromolar potency against E. coli DNA gyrase (IC50 = 0.8 and 0.9 μM, respectively), and all derivatives 2–7 showed ameliorated inhibitory capacity against the remaining tested topoisomerases, especially S. aureus topoisomerase IV.
    From the modeling and WaterMap results, compound 7, harboring a large 7-OCH3 group, was predicted to displace the high-energy hydration sites from this region to a greater extent. This ability was likely reflected in the overall profile of compound 7, with IC50 values of 1–7 μM for all four enzymes.
    Modeling suggested that there was a limited scope for modification of any other positions on the isoquinoline ring. A few substitutions of the 3-position were considered, which generally confirmed this view (compounds 8–12). Small groups, such as 3-F (8), 3-Cl (9), and 3-CH3 (11), retained or improved the general inhibitory profile with respect to 1. In particular, compounds 8, 9, and 11 showed significantly enhanced inhibition of S. aureus topoisomerase IV (IC50 = 7.1, 10.2, and 7.5 μM, respectively). Conversely, larger groups, such as 3-CN (10) and 3-OCH3 (12), showed poor inhibitory profiles overall.
    These findings are entirely consistent with data reported in the literature for other NBTIs (Figure 1). Indeed, the vast majority of NBTIs has small substituents similarly placed in the 3- and 7-positions of the isoquinoline ring, as discovered in the current work.
    Finally, the replacement of the isoquinoline ring with a 1,6-naphthyridine moiety (13) resulted in weakening of inhibitory potency.

    RHS SAR

    RHS modifications were centered on the introduction of different substituents at various positions of the coumarin rings of 1 and 2, as well as replacement of the bicyclic system by other heterocycles, affording compounds 14–22 (Table 4).
    Table 4. SAR of the Right-Hand Side (RHS)
    a

    IC50 values were calculated on concentration–response curves using the global curve fit nonlinear regression tool. Compounds were assayed at eight concentrations in duplicate with twofold or half-log dilutions starting from 100 μM.

    b

    Compounds were tested in DNA gyrase supercoiling assay kit (Norwich, U.K.).

    c

    Compounds were tested in topoisomerase IV decatenation assay kit (Norwich, U.K.).

    d

    E. coli ATCC 25922.

    e

    S. aureus ATCC 29213.

    Models of compound 1 in the S. aureus DNA gyrase crystal structure (PDB code 2XCS)(28) showed the coumarin ring buried in a small, highly hydrophobic depression at the surface of the DNA gyrase (Figure 10), with the carbonyl moiety water-bridging to Arg122. Initial static modeling indicated a fairly limited scope for substitution of the coumarin, although dynamics-based calculations did indicate plasticity.
    The observed SAR was mostly consistent with these theoretical predictions, albeit with some exceptions (Table 4). Notably, hydrophobic analogues of 1, bearing a 6-Cl (14) or 6-F (15) coumarin, exhibited IC50 values in the range of 0.6–5.5 μM on the four enzymes, with considerable enhancement of the activity toward S. aureus topoisomerase IV compared with that of 1. Conversely, close analogues of 2 harboring a 3-CH3 (16) or 5-CH3 (17) coumarin resulted in the complete loss of activity against S. aureus topoisomerase IV. Replacement of the coumarin ring with a 5,6,7,8-tetrahydro-2H-chromen-2-one moiety (18) led to increased inhibition of S. aureus DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV but reduced the activity toward E. coli DNA gyrase, with respect to 1. Additional unsaturated derivatives of 2 were also evaluated. The fusion of the 2H-pyran-2-one ring with piperidine (19), tetrahydropyran (20), and tetrahydro-2H-thiopyran dioxide (21) resulted in relatively poor profiles toward S. aureus topoisomerases. This effect can likely be attributed to the high desolvation energy required for these polar moieties to pass from the solvent media to the hydrophobic binding pocket. Only the tetrahydrothiopyran ring of compound 22 provided a more balanced profile against the S. aureus enzymes.
    Overall, the SAR described herein highlight the 6-Cl and 6-F coumarin rings as suitable RHS moieties to be applied for the optimization process. Interestingly, these moieties represent a valuable RHS alternative to the heterocycles displayed by other NBTIs, most often a pyridine fused to a nonaromatic ring (Figure 1).

    Linker SAR

    To investigate the importance of the aminopropyl-piperazine moiety of compounds 1 and 2, various linker modifications were explored, affording derivatives 23–31 (Table 5).
    Table 5. SAR of the Linker
    a

    IC50 values were calculated on concentration–response curves using the global curve fit nonlinear regression tool. Compounds were assayed at eight concentrations in duplicate with twofold or half-log dilutions starting from 100 μM.

    b

    Compounds were tested in DNA gyrase supercoiling assay kit (Norwich, U.K.).

    c

    Compounds were tested in topoisomerase IV decatenation assay kit (Norwich, U.K.).

    d

    E. coli ATCC 25922.

    e

    S. aureus ATCC 29213.

    Understanding the SAR around the linker is quite complicated from a modeling perspective. While the LHS and RHS moieties of the ligand have well-defined binding sites, the linker environment is ambiguous, being determined by the “void” between the DNA strand and protein. This open environment enables multiple transient interactions with polar residues while retaining high solvent exposure (Figure 11).
    Unfortunately, technologies such as docking, which generally use a rigid protein model, do not appropriately take into account the inherent mobility of this region. Additionally, naı̈ve molecular mechanics-based approaches, which either neglect the effect of the solvent entirely or approximate it via some type of continuum model, are unable to capture the contribution of discrete waters. Indeed, specific bridges may be formed between groups only if their geometric arrangements are favorable. Consequently, a simple MD-based approach, a technique that inherently includes full flexibility and explicit solvation, was applied to investigate linker modification. Focusing on the linker moiety, MD simulations on compound 2 showed that, in the most representative binding pose of the ligand, the 1N-piperazine was protonated and indirectly interacted with Asp83′ via a water molecule, and the exocyclic amino group established a direct contact with Asp83′ (Figure 11). On this basis, different linker modifications were explored to tentatively engage the target in strong and direct interactions.
    N-methylation (23) of the exocyclic amino group in the linker of compound 1 or replacement of this group with an oxygen atom (24) resulted in generally poor inhibitory potencies toward the four enzymes due to the lost interaction with Asp83′. Replacement of the exocyclic amino group of 2 with an amide (25) was well tolerated by DNA gyrase enzymes, although loss of activity toward topoisomerases IV was observed.
    Modifications around the piperazine moiety were also explored. The piperazine ring of 1 was replaced with a piperazinone moiety (26), resulting in substantial loss of activity across all enzymes in both bacterial species. In fact, the N-amide of 26 is not prone to protonation, resulting in loss of the positively charged feature within the linker, which represents a key trait of NBTI target recognition.
    Modifications of the propyl chain afforded compounds 27–31. Replacement of the linear propyl chain of 1 with cis-(27) and trans-(28) 1,3-cyclobutyl rings showed that, while the overall inhibitory profile was retained or even improved with respect to 1, only the trans isomer exhibited activity toward S. aureus topoisomerase IV.
    Notably, introduction of a 2-OH substituent in the propyl chain of 2 resulted in the enantiomers (S)-29 and (R)-29, with a well-balanced multitarget profile in the single-digit micromolar range against the four enzymes. The symmetric conformation of the binding site, together with the high solvent exposure of the site, might explain the observed insensitivity of the system to the chirality of the ligand.
    The analogue of 1 bearing a shorter aminoethyl chain (30) presented decreased activity, suggesting that the reduced compound size did not allow spanning of the required distance from the DNA strand down to the hydrophobic depression in the protein. Replacement of the aminopropyl chain in 2 with a 2-hydroxybutyl chain ((±)-31) provided improved potency against S. aureus topoisomerase IV and retention of the activity toward the other enzymes.
    In aggregate, our findings support what is already seen for other NBTIs. Indeed, the majority of reported NBTIs contain LHS and RHS heterocycles typically linked by an eight-atom bridge, which, although generally quite flexible, can incorporate one or more aliphatic rings (Figure 1).
    Importantly, the 1-(piperazin-1-yl)propan-2-ol and 1-(piperazin-1-yl)propan-3-ol linkers explored herein differentiate the developed compounds against the NBTI scenario.

    Mix and Match SAR

    In an effort to combine the best modifications discussed above for the LHS, RHS, and linker and to further investigate the chemical space, compounds 32–36 were synthesized (Table 6).
    Table 6. SAR Modification around the LHS, RHS, and Linker
    a

    IC50 values were calculated on concentration–response curves using the global curve fit nonlinear regression tool. Compounds were assayed at eight concentrations in duplicate with twofold or half-log dilutions.

    b

    Compounds were tested in DNA gyrase supercoiling assay kit (Norwich, U.K.).

    c

    Compounds were tested in topoisomerase IV decatenation assay kit (Norwich, U.K.).

    d

    E. coli ATCC 25922.

    e

    S. aureus ATCC 29213.

    All compounds contained the 1-amino-3-(piperazin-1-yl)propan-2-ol linker combined with different LHS and RHS rings. Compound (±)-32, despite the non-optimal 1,6-napthyridine LHS moiety, showed a very promising and balanced inhibition profile, with an IC50 of 1.1 μM toward S. aureus DNA gyrase and IC50 values in the range of 0.15–0.3 μM against the remaining enzymes. Compound (±)-33 (Figure 1), bearing a disubstituted 3-fluoro-7-methoxyisoquinoline in the LHS region, was obtained by merging the LHS moieties of 7 and 8. Notably, compound (±)-33 showed a very high potency, with IC50 values of ≤0.1 μM for all tested enzymes.
    Modeling studies suggested that introduction of a H-bond acceptor at the 3-position on the coumarin ring might have been beneficial for binding affinity. Therefore, replacement of the RHS of (R)-29 with a 2H-1,3-benzoxazin-2-one moiety was envisaged, affording compound (R)-34 with a slightly improved profile. The introduction of a 6-fluoro substituent on the 2H-1,3-benzoxazin-2-one ring was also explored. In particular, combination of the 6-fluoro-2H-1,3-benzoxazin-2-one RHS with the 7-fluoroisoquinoline and 3,7-di-fluoroisoquinoline LHS moieties provided compounds (±)-35 and (±)-36 (Figure 1), respectively. Remarkably, compounds (±)-35 and (±)-36 turned out to be extremely potent and balanced inhibitors, with excellent IC50 values (20–50 nM) against all four enzymes, resulting in greater effectiveness than that of the reference drug ciprofloxacin. Additionally, considering the literature data for the most advanced NBTI compound GSK2140944, derivatives (±)-35 and (±)-36 were equipotent against S. aureus DNA gyrase and approximately onefold more potent against S. aureus topoisomerase IV.(15) The potency of compounds (±)-35 and (±)-36 could be qualitatively rationalized by modeling using a dynamics protocol similar to that employed for compound 2. MD showed rapid evolution of the initial docked pose of (±)-35 into the S. aureus DNA gyrase crystal structure (PDB code 2XCS)(28) toward the binding mode shown in Figure 12.
    Notably, (±)-35 established a far more extensive interaction network with the protein target than the parent compound 2. The linker of (±)-35 formed a bidentate interaction with Asp83′, while the nitrogen of the 2H-1,3-benzoxazin-2-one was water-bridged to Asp83.
    Remarkably, compounds (±)-33, (±)-35, and (±)-36 were the most potent compounds identified in this investigation and effectively targeted both DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV in the tested bacterial strains. Conversely, fluoroquinolones preferentially target DNA gyrase in Gram-negative pathogens and topoisomerase IV in Gram-positive pathogens.(9) Taken together, these results indicate that compounds (±)-33, (±)-35, and (±)-36 have a distinct mechanism of action and more balanced activity than fluoroquinolones.

    Antibacterial Activity

    Parent compound 1 and compounds with single-digit micromolar potency toward the four enzymes were tested for in vitro antibacterial activity against a representative panel of Gram-negative and Gram-positive strains, including E. coli ATCC 25922, Pseudomonas aeruginosa ATCC 27853, S. aureus ATCC 29213, and S. aureus BAA-1720 (Table 7).
    Table 7. MICs of Selected Compounds and Reference Compound Ciprofloxacin against Representative Gram-Positive and Gram-Negative Strains with and without Human Plasma, Calculated PPB Levels
     MIC (μg/mL)a 
    compdE. coli ATCC 25922bP. aeruginosa ATCC 27853cS. aureus ATCC 29213bS. aureus BAA-1720bPPBd (%)
    ciprofloxacin0.004/0.0040.50.25/0.25>4/>429.6
    14>32>32>3297.4
    3284295.8
    42>88493.4
    7482195.6
    8444296.8
    140.548495.2
    150.5 4296.1
    (R)-29241190.8
    (S)-294810.590.8
    (±)-318>81493.4
    (±)-32284490.5
    (±)-330.25/>840.03/80.03/494.5
    (R)-344>80.25197.2
    (±)-350.25/>840.03/>80.25/>895.4
    (±)-360.12/>820.03/40.03/496.2
    a

    Minimum inhibitory concentrations were determined according to guidelines of the CLSI.

    b

    MIC in Mueller-Hinton broth/MIC in Mueller-Hinton broth with 50% human serum.

    c

    MIC in Mueller-Hinton agar.

    d

    PPB values were calculated using ACD/Percepta 2017.2.

    Overall, meaningful correlation between enzymatic inhibition and cellular potency was observed. Interestingly, the dual targeting of DNA gyrase as well as topoisomerase IV was reflected in good MICs. Indeed, while compound 1 with poor activity against S. aureus topoisomerase IV became inactive in S. aureus whole-cell assay, compounds with a more balanced dual target profile (i.e., 3, 4, 7, 8, 15, (R)-29, (S)-29, and 31–36) showed more favorable MIC values. Importantly, the improved antimicrobial activity against S. aureus seems to be correlated to the balanced dual-targeting profile of our molecules rather than to the enhanced S. aureus topoisomerase IV inhibitory activity. Indeed, compounds 11 and 20 with single-digit micromolar potency against S. aureus topoisomerase IV but poorer activity toward S. aureus DNA gyrase became inactive in S. aureus whole-cell assay (see the Supporting Information), confirming the potential of the multitarget approach. Having said that, the generation of spontaneous resistant mutants against tested compounds would ultimately confirm the putative dual inhibition.
    In the whole dataset, compounds (±)-33, (±)-35, and (±)-36 have been identified as the most promising in terms of antibacterial effect. Notably, the aforementioned compounds were more potent against S. aureus ATCC 29213 (MIC = 0.03 μg/mL) and the fluoroquinolone-resistant S. aureus BAA-1720 strain (MIC values 0.03–0.25 μg/mL) than the reference drug ciprofloxacin (S. aureus ATCC 29213 (MIC = 0.25 μg/mL) and S. aureus BAA-1720 (MIC > 4 μg/mL)). Importantly, the antibacterial activity against E. coli was also retained.
    The antimicrobial profiles of compounds (±)-33, (±)-35, and (±)-36 were further evaluated against other ESKAPE (Enterococcus faecium, S. aureus, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Acinetobacter baumannii, P. aeruginosa, and Enterobacter spp.) pathogens,(37) comprising Gram-positive enterococci as well as the Gram-negative species Haemophilus influenzae, N. gonorrhoeae, and K. pneumoniae.
    Compounds (±)-33, (±)-35, and (±)-36 showed potency toward vancomycin-sensitive (Van-S) and vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus faecalis and E. faecium, which are important etiological agents in nosocomial infections (Table 8, ciprofloxacin and vancomycin included as reference compounds).
    Table 8. Antibacterial Activity of Compounds (±)-33, (±)-35, and (±)-36 and Reference Compounds Ciprofloxacin and Vancomycin against Selected Gram-Positive Pathogens
     MIC (μg/mL)a
    compdE. faecium APV 00420 (Van-B)E. faecalis ATCC 29212E. faecalis APV 00404 (Van-S)E. faecalis APV 00406 (Van-S)E. faecalis APV 00408 (Van-A)E. faecalis APV 00409 (Van-A)E. faecium APV 00422 (Van-A)E. faecium APV 00424 (Van-A)E. faecium APV 00553 (Van-B)E. faecalis APV 00623 (Van-S)E. faecium APV 00626E. faecium APV 00627
    ciprofloxacin>3212646432128>1281282164
    vancomycin>8421>128>128>128>128>1282>128>128
    (±)-330.120.25n.d.n.d.n.d.n.d.n.d.n.d.n.d.n.d.n.d.n.d.
    (±)-3510.50.250.250.250.120.250.120.50.5161
    (±)-360.250.120.120.060.060.060.120.060.250.12320.5
    a

    Minimum inhibitory concentrations were determined according to guidelines of the CLSI. Van-A: bacterial strain resistant to vancomycin and teicoplanin. Van-B: bacterial strain resistant to vancomycin but sensitive to teicoplanin. Van-S: vancomycin-sensitive strain. n.d.: not determined.

    Moreover, the three compounds were active against fastidious Gram-negative H. influenzae (H128 and ATCC 49766) and N. gonorrhoeae (ATCC 19424) and moderately active against the nonfastidious K. pneumoniae (ATCC 700603) (Table 9, ciprofloxacin and vancomycin included as reference compounds).
    Table 9. Antibacterial Activity of Compounds (±)-33, (±)-35, and (±)-36 and Reference Compounds Ciprofloxacin and Vancomycin against Selected Gram-Negative Pathogens
     MIC (μg/mL)a
    compdH. influenzae H128 (quinolone-S)H. influenzae ATCC 49766 (quinolone-S)N. gonorrhoeae ATCC 19424K. pneumoniae ATCC 700603 (ESBL; quinolone-S)
    ciprofloxacin0.0080.015≤0.060.125
    vancomycin>8>8 >8
    (±)-330.50.5≤0.064
    (±)-350.120.25≤0.064
    (±)-360.060.12≤0.061
    a

    Minimum inhibitory concentrations were determined according to guidelines of the CLSI. Quinolone-S: quinolone-sensitive. ESBL: extended spectrum β-lactamases.

    Remarkably, the in vitro activities of compounds (±)-33, (±)-35, and (±)-36 were approximately comparable or even more potent against tested E. coli, S. aureus, H. influenzae, and N. gonorrhoeae strains than reported for GSK2140944.(14,38)
    Overall, compounds (±)-33, (±)-35, and (±)-36 showed a promising broad antibacterial spectrum against both wild-type and fluoroquinolone-resistant strains.
    The effect of human serum on the in vitro activity of compounds (±)-33, (±)-35, (±)-36, and ciprofloxacin against E. coli ATCC 25922, S. aureus ATCC 29213, and S. aureus BAA-1720 was also investigated. The antimicrobial potency of compounds (±)-33, (±)-35, and (±)-36 was affected by the presence of human serum (MIC elevations of 32-fold to >267-fold), whereas the MICs of ciprofloxacin remained unchanged (Table 7). These results correlated with the predicted high plasma binding levels (94–96%) for compounds (±)-33, (±)-35, and (±)-36 (Table 7). Indeed, for antibiotics, elevated plasma protein binding (PPB) is often, although not always, accompanied with a certain loss in microbiological activity. Having said that, it has been widely recognized that PPB may not be associated with diminished efficacy in vivo for the exact reasons stated below. Indeed, serum shift in vitro does not include metabolism and efflux that, in a living system, remove unbound drug and affect the average unbound plasma concentration. Additionally, several lead optimization strategies focused on reducing PPB levels to improve pharmacological activity were unsuccessful. The misconception was that increasing the fraction unbound would increase the average unbound plasma concentration responsible for the pharmacodynamic effects. However, in vivo unbound drug concentration is usually unchanged by PPB. Indeed, lower binding leads to higher in vivo clearance because more free drug molecules are available for metabolism and elimination, resulting in a zero net increase in average unbound plasma concentration. Therefore, serum shift and elevated in vitro PPB should not discourage drug candidate selection.(39)

    Cytotoxicity

    Compounds (±)-33, (±)-35, and (±)-36 were tested on five human cell lines to evaluate their cytotoxic effect (Table 10).
    Table 10. MIC Values of Compounds (±)-33, (±)-35, and (±)-36 with Respect to E. coli ATCC 25922 and S. aureus ATCC 29213 and Their Cytotoxic Profiles on Human Liver Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HepG2), Human Embryonic Kidney 293 (HEK293), Human Colorectal Adenocarcinoma (HT-29), Human Corneal Epithelial (HCE-2), and Human Keratinocyte (HaCaT) Cell Lines
     MIC (μM)aIC50 (μM)b    
    compdE. colicS. aureusdHepG2eHEK293eHT-29fHCE-2fHaCaTfSIgSIhSIiSIj
    (±)-331.0<0.122566>100>150 25>20866>5500
    (±)-352.140.215580   2626237381
    (±)-361.02<0.123152  >10030>25851>433
    a

    Minimum inhibitory concentrations were determined according to guidelines of the CLSI.

    b

    IC50 values were calculated on concentration–response curves using the global curve fit nonlinear regression tool.

    c

    E. coli ATCC 25922.

    d

    S. aureus ATCC 29213.

    e

    Concentration–response curves were performed for each compound by testing eight concentrations in triplicate with threefold dilutions starting from 100 to 0.030 μM after incubation for 48 h at 37 °C.

    f

    Concentration–response curves were performed for each compound by testing four/six concentrations in triplicate starting from 150 or 100 μM after incubation for 24 h at 37 °C.

    g

    SI = IC50 HepG2/MIC E. coli.

    h

    SI = IC50 HepG2/MIC S. aureus.

    i

    SI = IC50 HEK293/MIC E. coli.

    j

    SI = IC50 HEK293/MIC S. aureus.

    The tested compounds showed IC50 values ranging from 25 to 55 μM in the human liver hepatocellular carcinoma (HepG2) cell line, whereas the IC50 values were in the 52–80 μM range in human embryonic kidney 293 (HEK293) cells after incubation for 48 h. The selectivity index (SI) was calculated by comparing compound IC50 values in the HepG2 and HEK293 cell lines against the MIC of the same compound in E. coli ATCC 25922 and S. aureus ATCC 29213. Compounds (±)-33, (±)-35, and (±)-36 exhibited moderate SI values for E. coli ATCC 25922 (25- to 66-fold), whereas a notable safety window (SI > 200) was observed for S. aureus ATCC 29213. Nonetheless, it must be specified that SI values were calculated as the ratio of cytotoxic data measured using 10% of fetal bovine serum over MICs without serum. Therefore, what was presented might reflect the best-case scenario. Indeed, considering the previously commented shift in MIC values with 50% of human serum, the calculated safety window will be overestimated. In terms of early toxicity signals, compound (±)-33 was also assessed in human colorectal adenocarcinoma (HT-29) and human corneal epithelial (HCE-2) cell lines, while compound (±)-36 was tested in human keratinocytes (HaCaT). Importantly, both compounds exhibited no sign of cytotoxicity against the selected lines at up to 100 μM after incubation for 24 h.

    hERG Inhibition

    Despite the excellent antibacterial properties, NBTI-induced hERG toxicity still remains a main obstacle for their advancement into clinical trials.(27) In this respect, compounds (±)-35 and (±)-36 were screened in automated electrophysiological patch clamp assay to assess hERG channel effects (see the Supporting Information for the experimental details). Compound (±)-35 showed moderate hERG activity (67%) expressed as percent inhibition at 10 μM concentration, whereas compound (±)-36 displayed reduced hERG liability (24% inhibition at 10 μM). Based on the data, the hERG margin of safety will need to be improved for an eventual drug candidate. Indeed, the IC50 value for hERG binding with the reference NBTI compound GSK2140944 was 1.4 mM,(26) which is considerably higher than values registered by other discontinued NBTIs.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    We have shown herein how an initial set of SBVS and pharmacophore- and shape-based models can be used to screen a library of 30,000 compounds, including Angelini proprietary compounds, and ultimately identify a couple of distinct chemical series suitable for optimization. The validity of our model was presented by resolution of the cocrystal structure of one of the initial hits (ID-130) bound to S. aureus DNA gyrase. Importantly, this X-ray investigation revealed a mechanism of action for compound ID-130 that was distinct from that of fluoroquinolones and in agreement with the NBTI binding mode. This finding represented the basis for embracing a hit-to-lead campaign toward the development of novel antibacterial agents. Considering the promising antimicrobial profile of hit ID-130, we exploited the physical relevance of our computational models to support the optimization strategy. Our efforts led to the discovery of new derivatives 1–36 containing typical NBTI molecular features. The combination of novel and unique LHS and RHS moieties resulted in an original NBTI series. Notably, compounds (±)-33, (±)-35, and (±)-36 showed balanced multitarget activity against E. coli and S. aureus DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV enzymes. Furthermore, compounds (±)-33, (±)-35, and (±)-36 exhibited excellent efficacy against a representative panel of Gram-negative and Gram-positive pathogens, as well as clinically relevant resistant strains, that was competitive with that of established antibiotics (i.e., ciprofloxacin and vancomycin) and known NBTIs previously reported in the literature.(11−26) Despite the good antibacterial profiles, the MIC values of compounds (±)-33, (±)-35, and (±)-36 were affected by the presence of human serum, likely due to high PPB levels. Nevertheless, there is evidence in the literature that serum shift and elevated PPB might not correlate with in vivo average unbound plasma concentration and should not discourage drug candidate selection.
    Despite the fact that preliminary cytotoxicity investigation revealed the favorable safety profiles of these compounds, hERG liability was identified as a potential criticism as typically observed for the NBTI class. The fine-tuning of NBTI physicochemical properties could offer a promising solution toward diminishing hERG-related issues while retaining antibacterial potency.
    Overall, the piperazine derivatives reported herein represent a new chemotype in the NBTI landscape that has further potential for optimization and might serve as a basis for the future development of suitable candidates to be tested in an in vivo model of bacterial infection and pursued for the treatment of serious infections.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Some of the images included in the present work were obtained using the software PyMOL.(40)

    Chemistry: General Information and Synthetic Procedures

    Reagents and starting materials were purchased from commercial sources and used as received.
    Microwave-assisted reactions were carried out in a Biotage Initiator+ microwave synthesizer. Reaction progress was monitored by thin-layer chromatography (TLC, Merck silica gel 60 F254 plates, 0.04–0.063 mm) or UPLC-QTOF chromatography (Waters SYNAPT MS-ACQUITY UPLC system).
    Final compounds were purified by semipreparative HPLC or standard flash chromatography on silica gel, when appropriate. Semipreparative HPLC purification was run using an X-Bridge Prep C18 5 μm column (Waters) through a Waters 2767 Sample manager, Waters 2478 dual λ absorbance detector, and Waters Micromass ZQ single quadrupole mass spectrometer with an electrospray ionization (ESI) source. Samples were dissolved in DMSO/CH3CN (1:1; 50 mg/mL). Purification was accomplished using a proper gradient of phase A (CH3CN + 0.1% formic acid) and phase B (H2O + 0.1% formic acid) and a 40 mL/min flow rate at 25 °C. Fraction collection was managed by MassLynx software (v. 4.1).
    Compound purity and molecular mass were determined by high-pressure liquid chromatography (HPLC) and high-resolution mass spectrometry (UPLC-QTOF). HPLC analysis was carried out through a pump/autosampler (Waters Alliance 2695), UV photo diode array detector (Waters 2996), and Waters system data management (Empower 2) using a Suplex pKb-100 (250 × 4.6 mm, 5 μm) column. For UPLC-QTOF, an Acquity BEH C18 (2.1 × 50 mm, 1.7 μm) column was used, and a positive ion mode in the “VOptics” configuration was employed. Leucine-enkephalin (200 pg/μL) was used as the lock mass to provide authenticated exact mass measurement in MS and MS/MS modes within 5 ppm RMS mass accuracy. NMR values were obtained using a Bruker Avance system (300, 400, and 500 MHz). All resonance bands were referenced to tetramethylsilane (internal standard). For 1H-NMR spectroscopy: s = singlet; d = doublet; t = triplet; q = quartet; quin = quintet; dd = double doublet; dt = double triplet; ddd = double double doublet; dtd = double triple doublet; m = multiplet; br = broad; J = coupling constant (Hz); and δ = chemical shift (ppm).
    1H-NMR and 13C-NMR spectra of the final compounds were acquired on the corresponding hydrochloride salts, unless otherwise specified. The salts were prepared by dissolving the product in DCM and the minimum required amount of MeOH and by adding HCl (1 M solution in Et2O), causing precipitation. The solvents were evaporated under reduced pressure, and the residue was triturated with Et2O. The resulting solid was dried to give the corresponding hydrochloride salt. All compounds tested possessed a purity of ≥95%.
    General procedures A–G and experimental details of intermediates with general formulas I–XX are reported in the Supporting Information.

    General Procedure H: Synthesis of Compounds 1–4, 6, 11, 12, 14–23, 26–28, and 30

    A solution of the proper amines Va–Vk or XIVa (1.1 equiv), TEA (1.5 equiv), and pyran-2-ones VIa–VIj (1.0 equiv) in CH3CN was heated at 70 °C for 1 h. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting precipitate was filtered off and washed with CH3CN (2 × 1 mL). The resulting solid was further purified by semipreparative HPLC on silica gel to give the title compounds.

    General Procedure I: Synthesis of Compounds 5, 7–10, 13, and (±)-32

    A mixture of the proper 1-chloroisoquinoline or 5-chloro-1,6-napthyridine (1.0 equiv), K2CO3 (1.5–2.0 equiv), and 4-{[3-(piperazin-1-yl)propyl]amino}-2H-1-benzopyran-2-one VIIIa or 6-fluoro-4-{[2-hydroxy-3-(piperazin-1-yl)propyl]amino}-2H-1-benzopyran-2-one (±)-XXa (1.1–10 equiv) was submitted to three cycles of vacuum/N2 in a flask. DMSO was added, and the suspension was stirred at 110 °C for 5 h. The reaction was then allowed to cool to room temperature, diluted with water, and extracted with EtOAc. The organic phase was separated, washed with brine, dried over sodium sulfate, and evaporated under reduced pressure. The crude material was purified by flash chromatography on silica gel to afford the title compounds.

    General Procedure J: Synthesis of Compounds (R)-29, (S)-29, and (R)-34

    A solution of the proper amines XVa and XVb (1.1 equiv), TEA (1.5 equiv), and intermediate VIa (1.0 equiv) or XVIa (2.0 equiv) in CH3CN (2 mL) was stirred at 70 °C for 1 h, during which time a precipitate was formed. The reaction mixture was cooled, filtered, and washed with CH3CN. The crude material was purified by flash chromatography on silica gel to afford the title compounds.

    General Procedure K: Synthesis of Compounds (±)-35 and (±)-36

    To a suspension of chloride XVIb (3.0 equiv) in CH3CN, DIPEA (3.0 equiv) and proper amines (±)-XVc and (±)-XVd (1.0 equiv) were added at 0 °C. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 15 h, and then the resulted solid was filtered, washed with water, and dried. The crude material was purified by flash chromatography on silica gel, affording the final compounds (±)-35 and (±)-36 as racemates.

    4-({3-[4-(Isoquinolin-1-yl)piperazin-1-yl]propyl}amino)-2H-chromen-2-one (1)

    The title compound was obtained according to general procedure H using 3-[4-(isoquinolin-1-yl)piperazin-1-yl]propan-1-amine Va (141 mg, 0.52 mmol), TEA (107 μL, 0.78 mmol), 2-oxo-2H-1-benzopyran-4-yl trifluoromethanesulfonate VIa (153 mg, 0.52 mmol), and CH3CN (5 mL). Yield = 45%. LCMS m/z [M + H]+, 415.2; HRMS (ESI): [M + H]+, 415.2128; found, 415.2136; HPLC purity: 100%, Rt = 14.12 min; 1H-NMR of the hydrochloride salt (300 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ 11.07 (br s, 1H), 8.19 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 8.15 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 1H), 8.08 (d, J = 6.0 Hz, 1H), 8.00 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 1H), 7.95 (t, J = 5.5 Hz, 1H), 7.85 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 1H), 7.73–7.67 (m, 1H), 7.63–7.58 (m, 1H), 7.57 (d, J = 6.0 Hz, 1H), 7.39–7.28 (m, 2H), 5.27 (s, 1H), 4.00 (d, J = 13.3 Hz, 2H), 3.65 (d, J = 10.5 Hz, 4H), 3.50–3.34 (m, 4H), 3.30 (td, J = 4.8, 9.4 Hz, 2H), 2.14 ppm (quin, J = 7.3 Hz, 2H); 13C-NMR (125 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ 161.5, 157.6, 153.1, 153.0, 138.2, 132.1, 131.9, 127.7, 127.6, 126.2, 123.2, 122.7, 120.4, 116.9, 116.4, 114.5, 81.6, 53.4, 50.6, 47.9, 21.8 ppm.

    6-Chloro-4-({3-[4-(isoquinolin-1-yl)piperazin-1-yl]propyl}amino)-2H-chromen-2-one (14)

    4-({3-[4-(7-Fluoroisoquinolin-1-yl)piperazin-1-yl]propyl}amino)-5,6,7,8-tetrahydro-2H-pyrano[3,2-c]pyridin-2-one (19)

    4-{3-[4-(Isoquinolin-1-yl)piperazin-1-yl]propoxy}-2H-chromen-2-one (24)

    NaH (60% dispersion in mineral oil, 15 mg, 0.37 mmol, 1.0 equiv) was added to a stirred solution of 4-hydroxy-2H-1-benzopyran-2-one (60 mg, 0.37 mmol, 1.0 equiv) in CH3CN (4 mL). The suspension was stirred at room temperature for 30 min and then added to a solution of 3-[4-(isoquinolin-1-yl)piperazin-1-yl]propyl methanesulfonate Xa (0.37 mmol, 1.0 equiv) in CH3CN (4 mL). K2CO3 (76 mg, 0.55 mmol, 1.5 equiv) was added, and the mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 2 h. The volatiles were removed under reduced pressure, and the residue was dissolved in DCM and washed with water and brine. The organic phase was dried over sodium sulfate, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was chromatographed on silica gel eluted with a gradient of 0–10% MeOH/NH4OH (95/5) in DCM to give the title compound. Yield = 51%. LCMS m/z [M + H]+, 416.3; HRMS (ESI): [M + H]+, 416.1969; found, 416.1975; HPLC purity: 98.1%, Rt = 17.12 min; 1H-NMR of the hydrochloride salt (300 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ 11.42 (br s, 1H), 8.20 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 8.10 (d, J = 6.0 Hz, 1H), 8.00 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 1H), 7.95 (dd, J = 1.4, 7.9 Hz, 1H), 7.85 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 1H), 7.73–7.66 (m, 2H), 7.57 (d, J = 6.0 Hz, 1H), 7.43–7.37 (m, 2H), 5.95 (s, 1H), 4.38 (t, J = 5.6 Hz, 2H), 4.01 (d, J = 13.1 Hz, 2H), 3.73–3.65 (m, 4H), 3.47–3.343 (m, 4H), 2.44–2.37 ppm (m, 2H); 13C-NMR (125 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ 164.6, 161.5, 157.3, 152.7, 138.2, 132.7, 132.4, 127.8, 127.6, 126.3, 124.0, 123.1, 120.4, 116.4, 116.3, 115.0, 90.7, 66.7, 52.7, 50.5, 47.9, 22.6 ppm.

    3-[4-(7-Fluoroisoquinolin-1-yl)piperazin-1-yl]-N-(2-oxo-2H-chromen-4-yl)propanamide (25)

    A mixture of 2-oxo-2H-1-benzopyran-4-yl trifluoromethanesulfonate VIa (149 mg, 0.51 mmol, 1.3 equiv), 3-[4-(7-fluoroisoquinolin-1-yl)piperazin-1-yl]propanamide XIa (117 mg, 0.39 mmol, 1.0 equiv), K3PO4 (165 mg, 0.78 mmol, 2.0 equiv), Pd(dba)2 (11 mg, 0.019 mmol, 0.05 equiv), and Xantphos (11 mg, 0.019 mmol, 0.05 equiv) was loaded into a Schlenk tube, which was filled with N2. Dry dioxane (4 mL) was added, and the resulting mixture was stirred at 100 °C for 30 min. The organic phase was washed with H2O, filtered through a hydrophobic frit (Phase Separator), and evaporated under reduced pressure. The residue was chromatographed on silica gel (SNAP 10) eluted with a gradient of 50–100% EtOAc in cyclohexane to obtain the title compound. Yield = 29%. LCMS m/z [M + H]+, 447.3; HRMS (ESI): [M + H]+, 447.1827; found, 447.1857; HPLC purity: 95.5%, Rt = 14.03 min; 1H-NMR of the hydrochloride salt (300 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ 10.81 (br s, 1H), 10.44 (s, 1H), 8.34 (dd, J = 1.4, 8.4 Hz, 1H), 8.16 (d, J = 5.8 Hz, 1H), 8.08 (dd, J = 5.8, 9.0 Hz, 1H), 7.86 (dd, J = 2.5, 10.3 Hz, 1H), 7.74–7.68 (m, 2H), 7.58 (d, J = 5.8 Hz, 1H), 7.47–7.43 (m, 2H), 7.24 (s, 1H), 3.85 (d, J = 10.5 Hz, 2H), 3.63–3.61 (m, 2H), 3.58–3.53 (m, 2H), 3.50–3.41 (m, 4H), 3.31 ppm (t, J = 7.0 Hz, 2H); 13C-NMR (125 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ 170.8, 161.0, 160.1 (d, J = 245.8 Hz), 158.3, 153.1, 146.5, 137.7, 135.0, 132.5, 130.6 (d, J = 8.5 Hz), 123.8, 123.6, 121.6 (d, J = 8.5 Hz), 121.2 (d, J = 24.6 Hz), 117.0, 116.4, 114.0, 109.4 (d, J = 23.8 Hz), 99.9, 50.9, 47.6, 31.1 ppm.

    4-(Isoquinolin-1-yl)-1-{3-[(2-oxo-2H-chromen-4-yl)amino]propyl}piperazin-2-one (26)

    The title compound was obtained according to general procedure H using 1-(3-aminopropyl)-4-(isoquinolin-1-yl)piperazin-2-one XIVa (85 mg, 0.30 mmol), TEA (57 μL, 0.41 mmol), 2-oxo-2H-1-benzopyran-4-yl trifluoromethanesulfonate VIa (80 mg, 0.27 mmol), and CH3CN (4 mL).     cis-4-({3-[4-(Isoquinolin-1-yl)piperazin-1-yl]cyclobutyl}amino)-2H-chromen-2-one (27)

    trans-4-({3-[4-(Isoquinolin-1-yl)piperazin-1-yl]cyclobutyl}amino)-2H-chromen-2-one (28)

    The title compound was obtained according to general procedure H using trans-3-[4-(isoquinolin-1-yl)piperazin-1-yl]cyclobutan-1-amine Vj (55 mg, 0.177 mmol), TEA (37 μL, 0.266 mmol), 2-oxo-2H-1-benzopyran-4-yl trifluoromethanesulfonate VIa (52 mg, 0.195), and CH3CN (2 mL). Yield = 35%. LCMS m/z [M + H]+, 427.4; HRMS (ESI): [M + H]+, 427.2129; found, 427.2122; HPLC purity: 99.5%, Rt = 14.87 min; 1H-NMR of the hydrochloride salt (500 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ 12.21 (br s, 1H), 8.29–8.23 (m, 2H), 8.07–8.01 (m, 3H), 7.91 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 1H), 7.75 (t, J = 7.7 Hz, 1H), 7.63–7.60 (m, 2H), 7.36–7.32 (m, 2H), 4.98 (s, 1H), 4.35–4.33 (m, 1H), 4.14–4.12 (m, 2H),4.01–3.98 (m, 1H), 3.85–3.83 (m, 2H), 3.69–3.66 (d, J = 11.4 Hz, 2H), 3.33–3.10 (m, 2H), 3.03–2.98 (m, 2H), 2.65–2.615 ppm (m, 2H); 13C-NMR (125 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ 161.2, 157.4, 153.0, 152.4, 138.3, 132.6, 131.9, 127.8, 127.6, 126.4, 123.2, 123.0, 120.4, 116.8, 116.4, 114.2, 82.8, 56.5, 48.0, 47.8, 43.0, 29.7 ppm.

    4-({(2R)-3-[4-(7-Fluoroisoquinolin-1-yl)piperazin-1-yl]-2-hydroxypropyl}amino)-2H-1-benzopyran-2-one ((R)-29)

    The title compound was obtained according to general procedure J using (2R)-1-amino-3-[4-(7-fluoroisoquinolin-1-yl)piperazin-1-yl]propan-2-ol (R)-XVa (80 mg, 0.26 mmol), 2-oxo-2H-1-benzopyran-4-yl trifluoromethanesulfonate VIa (70 mg, 0.24 mmol), TEA (50 μL, 0.36 mmol), and CH3CN (3 mL).     4-({(2S)-3-[4-(7-Fluoroisoquinolin-1-yl)piperazin-1-yl]-2-hydroxypropyl}amino)-2H-1-benzopyran-2-one ((S)-29)

    The title compound was obtained according to general procedure J using (2S)-1-amino-3-[4-(7-fluoroisoquinolin-1-yl)piperazin-1-yl]propan-2-ol (S)-XVb (53 mg, 0.17 mmol), 2-oxo-2H-1-benzopyran-4-yl trifluoromethanesulfonate VIa (45 mg, 0.15 mmol), TEA (36 μL, 0.26 mmol), and CH3CN (2 mL).     (±)-4-{4-[4-(7-Fluoroisoquinolin-1-yl)piperazin-1-yl]-2-hydroxybutyl}2H-chromen-2-one ((±)-31)

    To a solution of 4-{4-[4-(7-fluoroisoquinolin-1-yl)piperazin-1-yl]-2-oxobutyl}-2H-chromen-2-one XVIIIa (100 mg, 0.22 mmol, 1.0 equiv) in MeOH (8 mL), NaBH4 (18 mg, 1.1 mmol, 5.0 equiv) was added, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight.     (±)-6-Fluoro-4-({2-hydroxy-3-[4-(1,6-naphthyridin-5-yl)piperazin-1-yl]propyl}amino)-2H-1-benzopyran-2-one ((±)-32)

    The title compound was obtained according to general procedure I using 5-chloro-1,6-naphthyridine (430 mg, 2.61 mmol), K2CO3 (721 mg, 5.22 mmol), (±)-6-fluoro-4-{[2-hydroxy-3-(piperazin-1-yl)propyl]amino}-2H-1-benzopyran-2-one (±)-XXa (924 mg, 2.87 mmol), and DMSO (10 mL).     (±)-6-Fluoro-4-({3-[4-(3-fluoro-7-methoxyisoquinolin-1-yl)piperazin-1-yl]-2-hydroxypropyl}amino)-2H-1-benzopyran-2-one ((±)-33)

    DIPEA (1.7 mL, 9.57 mmol, 5 equiv) was added to a stirred suspension of 1-chloro-3-fluoro-7-methoxyisoquinoline (404 mg, 1.91 mmol, 1.0 equiv) and (±)-6-fluoro-4-{[2-hydroxy-3-(piperazin-1-yl)propyl]amino}-2H-1-benzopyran-2-one (±)-XXa (754 mg, 1.91 mmol, 1.0 equiv) in DMSO (15 mL).
